title: print! and panic! don't work on std platforms without pthreads

labels.name: T-libs-api
labels.description: Relevant to the library API team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: C-feature-request
labels.description: Category: A feature request, i.e: not implemented / a PR.

body:
Currently, using  `print!` or `panic!` with `std` requires thread local (and I think maybe mutex) support. This is a pain point for running Rust on systems without `pthread`/`TLS` support.

I work on an OS that works on embedded devices. We have a libc (a MUSL fork), and much of the Rust standard library runs out of the box on our system. However, since we roll our own threads, we don't have `pthread` support.

I've been working to get Rust running on our system, and this is an annoying issue. It isn't a big deal for `print!`, since it's trivial to roll our own, but it really matters for `panic!`. While it seems like we could just use a custom hook, we can't in practice since it involves taking a lock. When a library thread calls `panic!` we'd prefer to get an actual message, rather than a crash in our `pthread` stubs.

I think a solution for this would be to add an option to `std`, similar to `force_alloc_system `? This would disable all the complex infrastructure around prints and panics, and just do the absolute simplest thing. These functions can be implemented (with very similar functionality) on systems without `pthreads`, it's just a case of exposing them in some way.
